user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (const char *const str1,
                               const char *const str2,
                               size_t len)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)
  {
    const char c1 = str1[i];
    const char c2 = str2[i];
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
      continue;
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciiupper (char c)
{
  return (c >= 'A') && (c <= 'Z');
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of the standard library function memcmp is present in the provided code. MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ compares characters one-by-one using a length parameter (len) and the helper charsequalcaseless/isasciiupper functions; none of these call memcmp or other standard library comparison routines. Therefore there are no code fragments relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (which specifically forbids using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings) to investigate in the supplied code. Note also that the function performs a bounded (length-based) comparison rather than an implicit null-terminated string comparison, so it does not fall under the prohibition even if the inputs happen to be null-terminated.
